Description: Fragment of limestone miniature altar with a small depression carved on the top; bottom bearing a panel relief representing a variant of the sign of Tanit; sides roughly incised with grids and a caduceus (?).
Curator's comments: The style and iconography is close to art works of Phoenician or Punic origin. The figure, a variant of the Tanit sign, finds good parallels from Punic sites in Sardinia. See notably 6th-4th century BC votive stelae from Nora (Moscati 2001, 373-5). Moscati, S. 2001, ‘Stelae’, in S. Moscati (ed.), The Phoenicians, London & New York, 364–379.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (ME.5) (Phase 3)
